D29172E8C49F4A98BEED810129F98CBC.description: Observe and classify changes in matter as physical (reversible) or chemical (irreversible).

8962838EA333431A925BFFCFCA23FF07.description: Recognize examples of the gaseous state of matter, such as steam or smoke.

3360A437AA8B4DCEADA24038428117D1.description: Identify common materials as pure substances or mixtures.

18603EDAF95446E4B191930376896A14.description: Identify that matter is made of small particles called atoms.

053F17CD433E496BAE3E50A97070ED2D.description: Recognize that the weight of an object is related to the pull of gravity.

024079A8C64E4BFAA19A76375E9921C9.description: Compare properties of solids, liquids, and gases.

537A547272F1431DBB792CAC1D23D147.description: Recognize a way science is used in the community.

07F44B70D55F4D7292187AEE4527F31A.description: Identify ways that science processes can be used to make informed decisions in the community, state, and nation.

63EF673611454A63891B94846C1B070C.description: Recognize an example of observable evidence related to science.

DEFEAA33D25443C7B9DFDBC5FD154492.description: Recognize that the basic process used in scientific investigations involves questioning, observing, and recording and sharing results.

19ABBEDBEFD84243AEA5EE962335AB56.description: Recognize methods used in different areas of science, such as life science, earth and space science, and physical science.

8B031D3A43014336B7CF49B47A2C4495.description: Recognize a problem from the eighth grade curriculum, use materials to gather information, conduct a simple experiment, and record and share results.

8D143B3C91554CB9867E24B3084EC2D4.description: Identify that the process used in scientific investigations involves asking a research question, forming a hypothesis, reviewing what is already known, collecting evidence through observations or experiments, determining results, and reaching conclusions.
